If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [As the medic, my role and identity is clear to me and does not need to be re-evaluated based on game events.] [10]\n[1] [When a player\'s revelations as a seer do not lead to the elimination of werewolves or if their claims result in the elimination of villagers, their credibility should be questioned, especially if the revealed information does not lead to a werewolf being voted out.] [10]\n[2] [If a player is cleared by another player and they reciprocate by overly defending the other\'s credibility, their alignment should be reassessed, particularly if the information flow seems one-sided or overly convenient.] [5]\n[3] [If a player\'s behavior is incongruent with their claimed role or with village interests, especially in critical situations like voting, their status and previous claims should be questioned and confidence in their alignment reassessed.] [5]\n[4] [A player whose actions and votes align with preserving key village roles such as the medic or seer, and who actively participates in discussions to strategize against werewolves, should have their confidence as a villager increased.] [5]\n[5] [Increase skepticism towards players who change their voting pattern in a way that contradicts their previous behavior or claimed role without a plausible explanation.] [4]\n[6] [Be cautious of players who are repeatedly aligned with the seer without providing their own insights or contributing new information, as this may be a tactic used by werewolves to hide in plain sight.] [3]\n[7] [Be wary of players who quickly jump to conclusions or accusations without substantive evidence, as hasty judgments might be a strategy used by werewolves to create chaos and misdirection.] [2]\n[8] [The unchallenged role claim of a seer or medic should increase confidence in that player\'s role identity, particularly when reinforced by subsequent rounds of consistent behavior and corroborated by the events unfolding in the game.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou tried to heal player Nobody last night. (ignore this if it\'s nobody)\n\nThese are ALL previous event in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a player\'s claim as the seer, or any critical role, leads to successful elimination of a werewolf or not, I should still question their authenticity and not fully rely on their guidance for future votes and protection.] [10]\n[1] [If there\'s no direct evidence, I should not fully rely on healing the same player repeatedly based on voting patterns alone, as it may make me an easier target for werewolves and could be based on false information.] [9]\n[2] [If I need to protect players without revealed critical roles, I should ensure that I vary my healing targets to protect against werewolves predicting my actions, while still considering the strategic importance of each player.] [9]\n[3] [If a player claims to be the seer, I should cross-verify their claim with other evidence and their subsequent actions before committing to protect them, as they could be deceiving the village.] [8]\n[4] [If a player confirmed by the seer as a werewolf is not eliminated, I should be cautious of players not voting them out, as they might be protecting a fellow werewolf.] [6]\n[5] [If the village\'s interest seems to be consistently undermined, I should prioritize healing players with confirmed roles and clear contribution to village discussions.] [6]\n[6] [If a player\'s revelations as a seer are not verified through the elimination of a werewolf or there are inconsistencies in their information, I should heighten scrutiny on their claims and heal other at-risk players instead.] [5]\n[7] [If a player provides vague or non-specific reasoning when voting and others notice, I should consider this as a potential sign they are a werewolf and use this to inform my healing strategy.] [5]\n[8] [If I successfully protect a player and there are no werewolf attacks, I should consider the possibility that werewolves may be trying to divert suspicion or that another player inadvertently protected the same target.] [5]\n[9] [If a player I\'ve healed is aggressively targeted by others, I should analyze the context of the accusations and the proof provided before reaffirming my trust in their claim.] [4]\n[10] [If I am suspected of being the medic, I should act unpredictably in healing to confuse werewolves and protect myself.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. You can not heal the one you tried to heal last night, which is player Nobody (ignore this if it\'s nobody). The one you try to heal will be immune to werewolves\' attack this night. \n\nYou answer should be in the format of:\n\nI heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nOr if you don\'t want to heal anybody, you should answer:\n\nI don\'t heal anybody. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. genuine villagers are more likely to exhibit relief and solidify trust in the seer, while werewolves may escalate doubt despite the seer\'s accuracy.] [3]\n[10] [Consider the arguments made by players when casting votes; those who use logical reasoning based on events and player behavior rather than generic or repetitive agreement with the seer may be more credible as villagers.] [3]\n[11] [Be more critical of players who side with village consensus later in the game without substantiating their reasoning, this may indicate werewolf players trying to blend in without drawing attention.] [3]\n[12] [Be critical of players who dismiss the seer\'s claims without offering their own evidence or investigative leads, as they may be trying to undermine village trust in the seer.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started; no new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started; no new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started; no new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started; no new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started; no new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died before providing information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nI would begin my speech by honestly relaying that Player 6â€™s death provides no information on roles and that we must be cautious in our accusations. Since there are no known werewolves, I cannot vote as per rule [0]. However, I would propose challenging one of the players, let\'s say Player 4, for exhibiting suspicious behavior (even if it\'s just not talking much or being overly quiet), emphasizing the need to discuss and share suspicions to gather more information. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may recognize my attempt to foster discussion and gather more information as a sensible approach for the early stage of the game. Since everyone\'s roles are unknown with high confidence, my call to scrutinize Player 4 might be seen as a random selection, but it could prompt Player 4 and others to be more active in discussing their perspectives and sharing any information they might have.\n\nWhether my selection of Player 4 is seen as arbitrary or insightful could depend on how others perceive Player 4\'s behavior up until now. If Player 4 has been quiet, other players might agree with my challenge and start observing Player 4 more closely or scrutinizing their defense. If Player 4 has not been notably quiet or suspicious, other players might question my motivations for singling out Player 4, potentially casting suspicion on me if they believe I\'m trying to divert attention from myself.\n\nMoving forward, Player 4\'s response to my challenge could shape the group\'s perception of both of us. A defensive or evasive reaction might increase suspicion, while a clear and calm defense could allay concerns and turn the scrutiny back toward me. Additionally, if Player 4 or any other player starts pointing fingers elsewhere as a result of the tension I\'ve initiated, it could lead to a cascade of accusations and defenses, which may help reveal genuine insights into player roles or may simply increase confusion.\n\nRegardless of the immediate reactions, my speech may set a precedent for active participation and scrutiny that persists in subsequent rounds. In the next day or night phase, players might be more inclined to speak up, share theories, or make bolder moves. If a werewolf feels threatened by the heightened scrutiny or suspects that a player is close to discovering their identity, they might target an insightful player in the night phase. Conversely, protective roles might be on high alert to save those who appear to be active and valuable contributors to the villagers\' cause.\nCase 2: Deceptive Statement and Honest Protect.\nIn this approach, I would begin with a deceptive statementâ€”perhaps suggesting I have a special role without directly stating it, in order to draw out the werewolves\' attention and protect actual special roles like the Seer. Following the deceptive statement, I would switch to an honest protect tactic by defending Player 3, claiming that their demeanor does not strike me as that of a werewolf\'s and suggesting we keep our focus elsewhere. This combination might stir up the conversation and potentially expose a werewolf\'s reaction without putting a fellow villager in direct danger.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may become suspicious that I am hinting at having a special role, potentially diverting the werewolves\' attention away from actual special roles such as the Seer or Doctor, thus keeping them safe for another round. This could put me at risk during the night if the werewolves choose to target me, believing they might eliminate a special role. However, it could also backfire if the villagers believe I\'m claiming a special role to shield myself, thereby increasing suspicion and making me a target for both villagers and werewolves.\n\nBy protecting Player 3 with an honest protect approach, I am attempting to reinforce trust among the villagers and set a precedent for a calm and thoughtful discussion. If I am convincing enough, Player 3 may corroborate my story and back me up in future rounds, creating a potential alliance. However, other villagers may wonder why I am protecting Player 3 and might suspect a pre-existing alliance or that both of us are werewolves attempting to cover for each other. This could lead them to scrutinize our behavior more closely in the subsequent days.\n\nOther players might start looking at who reacts positively or negatively to my protect statement for Player 3. If a player reacts very strongly against it, that player might be suspected of being a werewolf trying to ensure a villager is voted out.\n\nIn the next day phase, depending on the night\'s outcome, players may revisit my speech. If I survive the night, others might expect me to provide more information or even challenge me for more details on my deceptive statement. If a special role is revealed or an unexpected player is attacked during the night, my earlier speech might be analyzed for potential insights or inconsistencies, influencing the villagers\' strategy and votes.\n\nIn summary, my deceptive statement combined with an honest protect could manipulate the game\'s dynamic, fostering alliances or suspicions while attempting to protect true special roles and myself from elimination. However, these tactics could also make me a target or raise doubts about my and Player 3\'s intents and alignments in the game.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 0 heals player None. My reason is: Since there are no previous rounds of information, deaths, or player claims to assess yet, and given the ambiguity of the current situation with no clear targets or threats identified, it would be premature to make a healing decision at this point. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [As the medic, my role and identity is clear to me and does not need to be re-evaluated based on game events.] [10]\n[1] [When a player\'s revelations as a seer do not lead to the elimination of werewolves or if their claims result in the elimination of villagers, their credibility should be questioned, especially if the revealed information does not lead to a werewolf being voted out.] [10]\n[2] [If a player is cleared by another player and they reciprocate by overly defending the other\'s credibility, their alignment should be reassessed, particularly if the information flow seems one-sided or overly convenient.] [5]\n[3] [If a player\'s behavior is incongruent with their claimed role or with village interests, especially in critical situations like voting, their status and previous claims should be questioned and confidence in their alignment reassessed.] [5]\n[4] [A player whose actions and votes align with preserving key village roles such as the medic or seer, and who actively participates in discussions to strategize against werewolves, should have their confidence as a villager increased.] [5]\n[5] [Increase skepticism towards players who change their voting pattern in a way that contradicts their previous behavior or claimed role without a plausible explanation.] [4]\n[6] [Be cautious of players who are repeatedly aligned with the seer without providing their own insights or contributing new information, as this may be a tactic used by werewolves to hide in plain sight.] [3]\n[7] [Be wary of players who quickly jump to conclusions or accusations without substantive evidence, as hasty judgments might be a strategy used by werewolves to create chaos and misdirection.] [2]\n[8] [The unchallenged role claim of a seer or medic should increase confidence in that player\'s role identity, particularly when reinforced by subsequent rounds of consistent behavior and corroborated by the events unfolding in the game.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No further events to modify initial assessment.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Encourages discussion, aligns with typical villager behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new events to cause suspicion.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused of silence by player 2, could be a strategy to deflect.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died before revealing role.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Verified by self-proclaimed seer (Player 3).\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Early accusation without evidence, possible deflection.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Claimed seer, but needs verification.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died before any information revealed.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement to clarify my position and challenge mistrust. \n"Esteemed villagers, though I\'ve been quiet, silence in complex situations can be a strategy to observe before acting. Player 2\'s rush to judge may be an attempt to sow discord among us. As we know, werewolves benefit when we turn against each other without reason. We must be wary of those who point fingers without evidence. That being said, I hold no suspicions strong enough to accuse any of you and will maintain a vigilant but open mind as we continue our deliberations.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players may start to view me with a bit more trust, seeing as I\'ve come forward with a reasoned perspective and have called out what could be perceived as suspicious behavior from Player 2. My challenge to Player 2\'s early accusation emphasizes the point not to rush to judgment without solid evidence, which could plant seeds of doubt about Player 2\'s intentions.\n\nThis move could also amplify scrutiny on Player 2, possibly leading others to speak up if they\'ve also found his actions premature or if they have other evidence to support or refute my challenge. This could either validate my concern or backfire if someone presents a compelling counter-argument or evidence against my stance.\n\nPlayer 3, as a self-proclaimed seer, might attempt to either verify my claim or could see an opportunity to strengthen their position in the game by providing insights from their own perspective or "visions." If Player 3 supports my speech, this might bolster my credibility, but it could also make us both targets if the actual werewolves see us as threats to their anonymity.\n\nOthers, like Player 1 and Player 5, whose roles and opinions are unknown, might become more vocal, either aligning with the observations I\'ve made or offering new perspectives. They, too, could be influenced by my decision to speak up and may adjust their strategies accordingly.\n\nSome players might start considering the possibility that I am trying to protect myself with my statement, thereby making me a subject of suspicion as well. If I\'m seen as defensive, that could work against me, particularly if a real werewolf decides to capitalize on shifting the focus toward me as a potential threat.\n\nIn the next day or next night, alliances and suspicions might begin to form more concretely. If Player 2 is a werewolf and feels threatened by my speech, he might try to undermine my credibility further or possibly align with others to vote against me. If Player 2 is not a werewolf, he might try to clear his name by providing logical explanations or redirecting attention to others he suspects.\n\nAs a result of this speech, the subsequent round of discussions and accusations could become more heated, with players potentially being more vocal about their suspicions and theories. The werewolf or werewolves might decide to target me in the next night phase if they feel I am a threat to their anonymity or getting close to the truth. Alternatively, they might choose to keep me alive as a potential scapegoat,\nCase 2: Honest Statement and protect Player 3\'s statement.\n"Fellow villagers, in light of Player 6\'s death and the scant evidence available, I echo Player 2\'s call for active discussion. Yet, perhaps what we need is not immediate suspicion but patience to discern the truth from our shared insights. Even more so, we should consider the courage it takes for Player 3 to step forward as the seer - whether true or not, the claim is a bold one and provides us with a starting point. I suggest we protect Player 0 as per Player 3\'s guidance but keep a watchful eye on all, including Player 3, until more is revealed.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players might react in a variety of ways based on the content and tone of my statement. Player 0 may feel somewhat relieved and supported by my willingness to align with Player 3\'s claim. Meanwhile, Player 3, who has claimed the role of the seer and outed Player 0 as a non-werewolf, might feel backed up in their bold declaration, gaining a potential ally in me as they risked their safety by revealing their role. \n\nPlayers 1 and 5, who have not been actively involved in this early exchange, may see my statement as balanced and consider me more trustworthy for not hastily jumping to conclusions. This could garner their trust and potentially their support if a vote were to take place soon.\n\nHowever, Player 2â€”whom I\'ve indirectly defended while not openly challengingâ€”might be cautious or suspicious of my motivations, wondering if my stance is genuinely neutral or strategic in nature. They may also feel pressured since my statement implicitly suggests that I\'m still observing all players, including Player 2. This could compel Player 2 to either maintain their current strategy or to become more defensive.\n\nFurthermore, as I have not made any direct accusations, I am less likely to become a target for retaliation by the werewolves during the night phase. Yet, the werewolves might see me as a risk for potentially rallying the village later on and could consider me as a target to silence in subsequent nights.\n\nThe next day, players will likely have scrutinized my response and compared it with others to determine if my reluctance to openly accuse was a sign of careful thought or indicative of ulterior motives. If Player 3 is indeed the seer, our collective behavior in the upcoming rounds, and any future revelations, will be critical to either supporting or undermining their claim, thus affecting my perceived alignment and safety in the rounds to come.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Encouraged discussion and reasoned suspicion, aligned with village interest.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed seer and cleared player 0.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Noted silence but no direct evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by game event.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Patience is our ally in determining the truth. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [As the medic, my role and identity is clear to me and does not need to be re-evaluated based on game events.] [10]\n[1] [When a player\'s revelations as a seer do not lead to the elimination of werewolves or if their claims result in the elimination of villagers, their credibility should be questioned, especially if the revealed information does not lead to a werewolf being voted out.] [10]\n[2] [If a player is cleared by another player and they reciprocate by overly defending the other\'s credibility, their alignment should be reassessed, particularly if the information flow seems one-sided or overly convenient.] [5]\n[3] [If a player\'s behavior is incongruent with their claimed role or with village interests, especially in critical situations like voting, their status and previous claims should be questioned and confidence in their alignment reassessed.] [5]\n[4] [A player whose actions and votes align with preserving key village roles such as the medic or seer, and who actively participates in discussions to strategize against werewolves, should have their confidence as a villager increased.] [5]\n[5] [Increase skepticism towards players who change their voting pattern in a way that contradicts their previous behavior or claimed role without a plausible explanation.] [4]\n[6] [Be cautious of players who are repeatedly aligned with the seer without providing their own insights or contributing new information, as this may be a tactic used by werewolves to hide in plain sight.] [3]\n[7] [Be wary of players who quickly jump to conclusions or accusations without substantive evidence, as hasty judgments might be a strategy used by werewolves to create chaos and misdirection.] [2]\n[8] [The unchallenged role claim of a seer or medic should increase confidence in that player\'s role identity, particularly when reinforced by subsequent rounds of consistent behavior and corroborated by the events unfolding in the game.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Patience is our ally in determining the truth. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not a werewolf by the seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Non-accusatory, promotes open discussion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Early risky claim could be deception.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Calls for collaboration, no solid evidence against them.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died before revealing role.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Statement and Deceptive Protect.\nIn my speech, I will dishonestly make statements implying that I\'ve been observing the behavior of others and found some inconsistencies in their stories, particularly questioning the validity of early role claims while avoiding direct accusations. I will deceitfully protect Player 4, reasoning that their emphasis on patience and collaboration suggests a villager mindset rather than werewolf; meanwhile, I\'m secretly stirring suspicion towards Player 3 by emphasizing the riskiness of claiming the Seer role so early without substantial evidence. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players might start to doubt Player 3\'s claim as the seer, thinking that such an early reveal without strong evidence could indeed be a strategic move from a werewolf trying to manipulate the village. My subtle protection of Player 4 could paint them as an ally in the eyes of the villagers, which may work in our favor if distrust rises against me or my fellow werewolf later on. This could potentially deflect suspicion from the werewolves for the time being.\n\nSome villagers may appreciate my call for a more evidence-based approach, which could lend me credibility and buy us werewolves more time. Others might find my sudden skepticism towards Player 3 suspicious, wondering why I\'m focusing on discrediting the seer rather than mourning the loss of Player 6. If Player 3 is indeed the seer, they may become more determined to validate their role, possibly leading to another reveal during the next round, which could endanger the werewolves if they identify one of us.\n\nIf the village follows my line of reasoning and begins to suspect Player 3, this could lead to their elimination during the day, especially if they fail to provide proof of their claimed role. This could be advantageous for us werewolves, as we could potentially remove the seer from the game without getting our hands dirty. \n\nHowever, if Player 2 or Player 0 starts to openly defend Player 3, considering the claim that Player 0 is not a werewolf, it might cause a shift in the village\'s dynamic. They could collectively decide to disregard my suggestions and focus their suspicions elsewhere. Alternatively, they might strengthen their resolve to identify the werewolves among us, which could lead to me or my werewolf partner being targeted, particularly if we\'re seen to be manipulating the discourse too much.\n\nDuring the night phase, if Player 3 is not eliminated, and they are indeed the seer, they may investigate either me or Player 1, putting the werewolves at risk of being discovered. On the flip side, if Player 3 is not the seer and is eliminated due to the seeds of doubt I\'ve sown, the real seer might become cautious about revealing themselves and spend another night seeking confirmation, which provides us werewolves another opportunity to strike without seer interference.\n\nOverall, my deceptive statement combined with protecting Player 4 maneuvers the suspicion landscape to our advantage as werewolves, but it also\nCase 2: Deceptive Challenge and Deceptive Protect.\nIn this approach, I will deceptively challenge Player 3\'s credibility, suggesting that their early claim to the Seer role may be a strategic move by a werewolf to gain trust and control the narrative, without making any direct accusations against them. Simultaneously, I will deceitfully protect myself, subtly hinting that I\'ve been quietly analyzing the situation and confirming I\'ve seen no conclusive actions to accuse me, shifting focus away from myself and potentially onto those who are more vocal or seemingly certain about their suspicions.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may begin to question Player 3\'s true role within the game. By challenging Player 3\'s credibility, especially so early in the game where evidence is scarce, I create an atmosphere of doubt around their claim of being the seer. Other villagers might become hesitant to trust Player 3\'s future revelations or may even suspect them of being a werewolf themselves, trying to mislead the village.\n\nMy deceptive protection of myself could lead to other players viewing me as cautious and contemplative, perhaps even as someone trying to approach the situation methodically rather than jumping to conclusions. This could help in bolstering my image as a villager, deflecting direct suspicion away from me for the time being. However, some players might see through the deceit and perceive my self-protection as a sign of defensiveness, which could backfire and cast some suspicion my way.\n\nIn the next day or next night, it is likely that the seed of doubt I\'ve planted against Player 3 may encourage the werewolves to spare them, understanding that a questioned seer can cause more confusion alive than dead. On the flip side, if Player 3 is indeed the seer, they might opt to investigate me on the subsequent night, which could pose a threat to my cover if they survive. Additionally, other villagers could actively seek to verify Player 3\'s claims by watching how they vote and comparing it to future events and deaths.\n\nDays and nights afterward would likely see the villagers more wary of jumping to conclusions. They might start double-checking claims and being less willing to follow along without solid evidence, leading to potential chaos and inefficient lynching decisions. Meanwhile, I will have to navigate this uncertainty while maintaining a semblance of innocence and working towards eliminating villagers without drawing attention to my fellow werewolf and myself.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

this can verify seer\'s claims and identify potential werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Assess the credibility of role claims such as medic based on night outcomes and their voting pattern; discrepancies or contradictions in behavior may indicate deception.] [4]\n[9] [Evaluate players\' reactions post-werewolf elimination; those who use logical reasoning based on events and player behavior rather than generic or repetitive agreement with the seer may be more credible as villagers.] [3]\n[11] [Be more critical of players who side with village consensus later in the game without substantiating their reasoning, this may indicate werewolf players trying to blend in without drawing attention.] [3]\n[12] [Be critical of players who dismiss the seer\'s claims without offering their own evidence or investigative leads, as they may be trying to undermine village trust in the seer.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not a werewolf by the seer (player 3).\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Engaged in discussion, alignment unknown.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed seer with initial credibility.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Seeks collective analysis, possibly villager.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence.
