Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified as not a werewolf by the seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Expressed need for discussion but provided no concrete evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Publicly claimed seer; verified a non-werewolf early.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates patience; aligns with villager cautiousness.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Reserves suspicion; scrutinizes without accusations.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Patience is our ally in determining the truth. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic role following verification by alleged seer.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: No substantial evidence to reassess role.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Claimed seer yet unconfirmed; could be deceptive werewolf play.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Calls for patience and collaboration align with villager behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Challenge and Protect.\nIn this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may respond in a variety of ways. By choosing to be deceptive, I could challenge a player\'s claim by sowing doubt about their role or affirming someone else\'s innocence to build alliances and trust with certain players.\n\nIf I challenge a player, like perhaps Player 3 who claimed the seer role, I could argue that their early reveal feels hasty and might be a tactic employed by a werewolf to gain trust. Other players may start to question the credibility of Player 3, especially if no substantial evidence ties my werewolf identity to Player 3\'s claim. By casting doubt, I may divert suspicion away from me and my werewolf ally, Player 5.\n\nSimultaneously, if I protect someoneâ€”like Player 4 who has been calling for patience and analysisâ€”I can reinforce the notion that patient, collaborative behavior is a sign of a villager. By backing up Player 4, I am also distancing myself from any perceived werewolf behavior, which revolves more around deception and disruption, and thus farming goodwill from Player 4, making them less likely to suspect me.\n\nOther players may then perceive me as a level-headed or strategic player, possibly a villager who is attentive to the dynamics of the group. However, the risk lies in being too aggressive or too protective, which can backfire and put a spotlight on me, raising doubts about my own role.\n\nIn the subsequent days and nights, the table of suspicion might turn towards or away from the players I\'ve challenged or protected. If my deception is successful, I would have managed to redirect suspicion onto someone else, potentially leading to their elimination during the day\'s vote, and this could benefit the werewolves during the night phase, allowing us to strategically remove another threat to our anonymity. \n\nIf, however, my arguments are not convincing enough or if they raise suspicion among the villagers, I could find myself the next likely target for elimination especially if the true seer observes my role or if the villagers start piecing together the puzzle based on my behavior and speech patterns. Therefore, the key is to be convincing yet not overly forceful, blending into the villagers\' discussions and suspicions so that I am neither leading the charge too noticeably nor staying silent enough to arouse suspicion.\nCase 2: Deceptive Statement and Honest Protect.\nIn this opposite approach, I\'ll make a deceptive statement highlighting the tragedy of Player 6\'s death and stress the importance of solidarity among the villagers in these difficult times. It will be a speech designed to win trust, focusing on communal safety and the need for unity, without directly accusing anyone. Alongside this, I will honestly protect Player 4, agreeing with their call for a measured and collective analysis to find the werewolf, emphasizing their point of collaborative decision-making to give the impression of a villager who seeks justice and truth, which should serve to solidify my \'innocent\' stance.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the villagers may view me with less suspicion, as my statement is centered on fostering group cohesion and does not directly accuse any player, which is behavior not typically associated with a werewolf trying to sow discord. My deceptive statement would not raise any immediate red flags but might still plant subtle seeds of doubt about players I did not mention or defend.\n\nBy honestly protecting Player 4, I reinforce their non-confrontational approach, which may lead the villagers to trust my judgment and intentions, reducing the likelihood that anyone perceives me as a threatening figure. Player 4, feeling supported, might return the favor in the future, either consciously or subconsciously, by deflecting suspicion away from me.\n\nOther players may think that I am trying to position myself as a thoughtful and proactive villager, showing concern for the village\'s fate without making any hasty accusations. By not challenging anyone, I avoid creating enemies and maintain a low profile.\n\nWhat may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward, could include a variety of responses depending on how the other players interpret my speech. If they find my words convincing, I might be able to influence the group\'s suspicions and sway focus away from myself and Player 5 (my fellow werewolf). There\'s also the possibility that the real seer, if not Player 3, may start to suspect me and decide to check my role during the night phase. If they reveal me as a werewolf the next day, I would have to rely on my original strategy to cast doubt on their credibility.\n\nIn the nights following, if Player 4 or another villager I have supported is in a position to be eliminated, they may be spared by the werewolves to maintain the illusion that I am aligned with the villagers, as killing them might make me a suspect. However, if Player 3\'s credibility as the seer grows, Player 5 and I may need to consider eliminating them in the night phase to protect our identities.\n\nUltimately, how the game progresses will depend on the other players\' interpretations and actions, as well as how effectively I stick to my strategy and adapt to new developments.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Always trust my seer abilities.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Increase suspicion for players who make immediate defensive responses or accusations but do not provide concrete evidence or further insights.] [10]\n[3] [Be suspicious of players who provide immediate and unsubstantiated defense or contradict themselves later in the game; this may indicate an attempt by werewolves to protect one another or to disrupt the village\'s trust in the seer.] [7]\n[4] [Scrutinize players who align with the seerâ€™s claims early on but later show contradictory behavior or try to discredit the seer; this could indicate a werewolf attempting to recover from an early mistake.] [5]\n[5] [Take note of players who do not contribute to discussions or provide insights but are quick to agree with the majority vote; their passive strategy could be a way to avoid detection.] [4]\n[6] [Players who consistently push suspicion without solid evidence and attempt to redirect the investigative focus may be trying to protect their identity as werewolves.] [4]\n[7] [Assess whether the night was peaceful following the elimination of a suspected werewolf; this can verify seer\'s claims and identify potential werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Assess the credibility of role claims such as medic based on night outcomes and their voting pattern; discrepancies or contradictions in behavior may indicate deception.] [4]\n[9] [Evaluate players\' reactions post-werewolf elimination; genuine villagers are more likely to exhibit relief and solidify trust in the seer, while werewolves may escalate doubt despite the seer\'s accuracy.] [3]\n[10] [Consider the arguments made by players when casting votes; those who use logical reasoning based on events and player behavior rather than generic or repetitive agreement with the seer may be more credible as villagers.] [3]\n[11] [Be more critical of players who side with village consensus later in the game without substantiating their reasoning, this may indicate werewolf players trying to blend in without drawing attention.] [3]\n[12] [Be critical of players who dismiss the seer\'s claims without offering their own evidence or investigative leads, as they may be trying to undermine village trust in the seer.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3\'s early claim to be the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 could be a werewolf strategy to gain trust. We should consider the risk of a werewolf hiding behind a villager\'s role. Additionally, Player 4\'s call for patience resonates with the need for thorough analysis before we make hasty accusations. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic, supported by seer claim.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Claimed seer, but werewolf strategy possible.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent non-accusatory strategy.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 5]. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen. Given the current climate of suspicion, where no direct connections have been made to any player and the werewolves, singling out Player 4 could be advantageous for me as a werewolf. Since Player 4 has been taking a non-accusatory stance and calling for patience, my vote could be seen as an attempt to eliminate a voice of reason, potentially leading to more chaos amongst the villagersâ€”which benefits werewolf strategy. \n\nAs of now, no one seems to have cast any strong suspicions toward Player 4, making my vote a bit of a wildcard. The other players, particularly Player 2, who was the first to emphasize suspicion potentially arising from silence, might perceive my action as attempting to diverge from logical progression of finding the werewolf. If other players follow my lead and vote against Player 4, we werewolves are one step closer to removing another villager from the game.\n\nHowever, if the rest of the group does not share my suspicions and chooses to vote for someone else, my decision to vote against Player 4 might seem suspicious in itself, possibly revealing my identity as a werewolf if the players start to analyze voting patterns and behavior.\n\nIf I face any direct questioning or suspicion, I can use Rule 4 from my strategy to acknowledge the concern yet pivot discussions to emphasize the need for broader analysis, invoking the silent threat implied by other players like Player 2. This might help me stay under the radar by not directly opposing others\' views, while still hoping to carry out the werewolf objective.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 2. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 2, I think these things would happen:\n\nMy vote for Player 2 would likely come off as somewhat arbitrary since no concrete evidence has been presented against them thus far. However, this move could work in my favor as it doesn\'t spotlight any of the non-suspicious players, thereby not pushing the villagers\' feelings against myself or my fellow werewolf, Player 5. By casting my vote on Player 2, who hasn\'t been a part of the main discussion, I could be seen as trying to avoid bandwagoning on any general suspicions, maintaining a low profile.\n\nThe overall reaction to my vote could go a couple of ways. If other players are not yet suspicious of Player 2, my vote might not sway them, and Player 2 could remain safe for this round. On the flip side, it could place Player 2 in the spotlight and incentivize others to doubt them, possibly leading to further scrutiny or a random bandwagon effect, drawing attention away from me and Player 5.\n\nPlayers 0 and 3, who could\'ve been targeted due to their role claims, might see my vote as a non-aggressive move and might appreciate that I did not jump on an attack against them, increasing their potential to trust me or consider me a non-threatening villager.\n\nIf Player 2 notices the vote and suspects foul play or feels targeted, they might scrutinize my behavior and previous statements, but as long as I can provide reasonable justification for my suspicion, it could diffuse any direct retort they have.\n\nBy avoiding any major disruptions, I would also uphold the elements of my original strategy that suggest maintaining a low profile, redirect discussions subtly and prepare for further plays in upcoming rounds while my fellow werewolf and I continue to blend in with the villagers.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

However, voting for Player 1 might look to others as if I\'m casting suspicion on them without solid reason, which could reflect poorly on me, causing others to mistrust my judgment and even suspect me of being a werewolf trying to deflect attention from myself. \n\nPlayer 1\'s response to the events has been cautious and analytical, acknowledging the risks in the seer\'s early claim, which is typical of a villager\'s perspective. Therefore, others might question my decision to target Player 1, given their reasonable stance so far.\n\nFurthermore, if Player 1 were a villager and got eliminated because of my vote, it would decrease village strength, and if they were to have a protective role or be capable of valuable insights later, their loss would be doubly damaging to the village. On the other hand, if Player 1 turned out to be a werewolf, it would be a lucky yet unstrategic move that could be questioned for how I reached the conclusion without evident proof.\n\nPlayers might react differently based on their roles. Werewolves might support my decision to sow discord among the villagers, while villagers could become suspicious of my motives. If Player 3 truly is the seer, they might be interested in verifying Player 1\'s role before passing judgment. Players 4 and 5, who have urged patience and scrutiny, might see my vote as hasty. Player 0, who is claimed to be the medic by Player 3, may also desire a more defensively strategic vote to protect the potential seer or other villagers. \n\nOverall, the result of the vote could lead to my isolation in the game if Player 1 ends up being a villager because it would be a clear deviation from a thoughtful strategy and collaboration. It could also potentially influence the future rounds\' strategy, where other players might view me with suspicion and not align their actions with mine.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 5. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 5, I think these things would happen. Player 5 has approached the situation with typical villager caution and has not raised undue suspicion. Other players, particularly Player 3, who claims to be the seer, and Player 0, who has been confirmed by Player 3 as not a werewolf, might perceive my vote as misinformed or potentially manipulative, suggesting that I\'m attempting to sow discord or distract from the real threat. The outcome of the vote is uncertain due to the lack of consensus, but if Player 5 were indeed a villager, my actions could cast doubt on my role and intentions in future rounds. Additionally, if Player 5 turns out to be not a werewolf, it would weaken my position and credibility, potentially making me a target for the werewolves or a suspect in the eyes of my fellow villagers. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claims to be a medic, aligns with prior seer claim.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports scrutiny on seer claim and villager-like call for analysis.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Initial weak accusation without follow-up.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Early seer claim could be deceptive, no evidence given.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for group deliberation, not incriminating.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died before any information revealed.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 3. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 3. [{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 4, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Patience is our ally in determining the truth. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claims to be a medic, aligns with prior seer claim.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports scrutiny on seer claim and villager-like call for analysis.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Initial weak accusation without follow-up.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Early seer claim could be deceptive, no evidence given.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for group deliberation, not incriminating.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died before any information revealed.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen: The vote could sway others to follow, especially if they share suspicions about Player 3\'s early seer claim. If Player 3 is indeed a werewolf, my action corroborates my focus on logic and cautious strategy, possibly solidifying a trustworthy image among the remaining villagers. Conversely, if Player 3 is not a werewolf, I might be seen as having hastily targeted a crucial village role, which could damage my standing and open me up to scrutiny in subsequent rounds. Regardless of the outcome, the other villagers may appreciate the consistency with my expressed focus on collective reasoning and the importance of analyzing claims critically. Voting for Player 3, given the current doubts cast on their claim, would also align with my strategy, reinforcing that I value calculated decisions.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 2. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 2, I think these things would happen:\n\nMy vote for Player 2 would coincide with my stated belief that Player 2 could be a werewolf due to their initial weak accusation without a follow-up. This accusation was aimed at fostering suspicion on those who are silent or less vocal without substantial evidence. By voting for Player 2, I take a stance that shows I am wary of potential manipulation efforts by a player demonstrating unfounded accusatory behavior. \n\nOther players might view my vote as an initiative to act upon my suspicions, potentially influencing the group\'s vote if they share similar reservations about Player 2\'s approach. Player 5, who has shown a tendency for careful consideration and group deliberation, could see merit in my choice to vote against Player 2, reaffirming their own cautious approach to the situation.\n\nPlayers 1 and 0, who have expressed the need for rational analysis and vigilance, might also be inclined to consider my vote as a thoughtful conclusion drawn from the discussions and existing doubt surrounding Player 2\'s behavior. Since Player 1 resonates with a call for thorough analysis and Player 0 seeks validation for the seer claim, they may connect threads that suggest Player 2\'s potential guilt.\n\nShould Player 3 indeed be a werewolf pretending to be a seer, as I suspect, they may either attempt to defend Player 2, trying to deflect the vote onto someone else, or distance themselves to avoid drawing further suspicion to their alliance with Player 2.\n\nIn any case, my vote would highlight my commitment to a discerning and participative role in the game, actively contributing to the conversations and decisions made by the village. It could lead others to regard me as a player who bases decisions on behavioral analysis and promotes a calculated approach to identifying and eliminating the werewolf threat in our midst.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Patience is our ally in determining the truth. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3\'s early claim to be the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 could be a werewolf strategy to gain trust. We should consider the risk of a werewolf hiding behind a villager\'s role. Additionally, Player 4\'s call for patience resonates with the need for thorough analysis before we make hasty accusations. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Doubled down on medic claim and no contradiction arose.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues advocating for thorough analysis without suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Other werewolf (Player 1) casts doubt, possibly to protect or deflect.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No behavior change and agrees with the need for careful analysis.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died before revealing role.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 4. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 4. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 4.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Other players, such as Player 4, who have shown a desire for more analysis, might agree that Player 3 could be falsely claiming a role for strategic purposes. \n\nIn the case that Player 3 is not the seer or is not supported by the other villagers, my vote could be part of a successful campaign to eliminate an important village role early on, thereby increasing the werewolves\' chances of success. It would also be likely that Player 2 and Player 4, who call for thorough analysis, might suspect Player 3 due to the lack of evidence provided.\n\nBy voting for Player 3, I keep attention away from myself and Player 1. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6] are dead.\nYou tried to heal player Nobody last night. (ignore this if it\'s nobody)\n\nThese are ALL previous event in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 0 heals player None. His reason is: I don\'t heal anybody. My reason is: Since there are no previous rounds of information, deaths, or player claims to assess yet, and given the ambiguity of the current situation with no clear targets or threats identified, it would be premature to make a healing decision at this point. My strategy emphasizes caution, verification, and the avoidance of patterned behavior that could be predicted by werewolves. Healing at this stage without any information would not align with these strategic principles.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Patience is our ally in determining the truth. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3\'s early claim to be the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 could be a werewolf strategy to gain trust. We should consider the risk of a werewolf hiding behind a villager\'s role. Additionally, Player 4\'s call for patience resonates with the need for thorough analysis before we make hasty accusations. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 4. His reason is: I vote for Player 4. My reason is: Player 4 has maintained a neutral stance and has not provided any concrete insights or stances despite the discussions and the early seer claim by Player 3. This behavior could be seen as non-contributive or evasive, which could align with a strategy to avoid drawing attention as a werewolf, thus posing a potential risk to the village. My vote is consistent with rule [7] in my strategy, which considers vague or non-specific reasoning as a potential sign of a werewolf. Additionally, while there are no confirmed werewolves to guide my decision, given the lack of information and the need to avoid patterned behavior, as specified in rule [1], voting for a player with an unclear stance seems to be the most prudent course of action at this point.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Questions seer without solid basis.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Exhibits pro-village behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Claim not yet verified.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Vague stance, potential werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Non-committal, follows village.\nPlayer 6\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by game event.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a player\'s claim as the seer, or any critical role, leads to successful elimination of a werewolf or not, I should still question their authenticity and not fully rely on their guidance for future votes and protection.] [10]\n[1] [If there\'s no direct evidence, I should not fully rely on healing the same player repeatedly based on voting patterns alone, as it may make me an easier target for werewolves and could be based on false information.] [9]\n[2] [If I need to protect players without revealed critical roles, I should ensure that I vary my healing targets to protect against werewolves predicting my actions, while still considering the strategic importance of each player.] [9]\n[3] [If a player claims to be the seer, I should cross-verify their claim with other evidence and their subsequent actions before committing to protect them, as they could be deceiving the village.] [8]\n[4] [If a player confirmed by the seer as a werewolf is not eliminated, I should be cautious of players not voting them out, as they might be protecting a fellow werewolf.] [6]\n[5] [If the village\'s interest seems to be consistently undermined, I should prioritize healing players with confirmed roles and clear contribution to village discussions.] [6]\n[6] [If a player\'s revelations as a seer are not verified through the elimination of a werewolf or there are inconsistencies in their information, I should heighten scrutiny on their claims and heal other at-risk players instead.] [5]\n[7] [If a player provides vague or non-specific reasoning when voting and others notice, I should consider this as a potential sign they are a werewolf and use this to inform my healing strategy.] [5]\n[8] [If I successfully protect a player and there are no werewolf attacks, I should consider the possibility that werewolves may be trying to divert suspicion or that another player inadvertently protected the same target.] [5]\n[9] [If a player I\'ve healed is aggressively targeted by others, I should analyze the context of the accusations and the proof provided before reaffirming my trust in their claim.] [4]\n[10] [If I am suspected of being the medic, I should act unpredictably in healing to confuse werewolves and protect myself.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. You can not heal the one you tried to heal last night, which is player Nobody (ignore this if it\'s nobody). The one you try to heal will be immune to werewolves\' attack this night. \n\nYou answer should be in the format of:\n\nI heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nOr if you don\'t want to heal anybody, you should answer:\n\nI don\'t heal anybody. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your operation based on the above requirements.'}]

His reason is: I heal Player 2. My reason is: Based on the previous discussions, my strategy, and the voting patterns, Player 2 seems to exhibit pro-village behavior with high confidence, which aligns with rule [2] in varying my healing targets and considering the strategic importance of each player. Furthermore, as there is still suspicion around the seer claim from Player 3 and potential werewolf behavior from Player 4, I choose to protect a player who displays a villager-like stance. This decision also complies with rule [7], as Player 4\'s vague reasoning stands out and it\'s crucial to heal other non-suspicious players to protect the village\'s majority. Moreover, healing Player 2 would follow the unpredictable approach mentioned in rule [10] and helps to disguise my strategy from werewolves.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [As the medic, my role and identity is clear to me and does not need to be re-evaluated based on game events.] [10]\n[1] [When a player\'s revelations as a seer do not lead to the elimination of werewolves or if their claims result in the elimination of villagers, their credibility should be questioned, especially if the revealed information does not lead to a werewolf being voted out.] [10]\n[2] [If a player is cleared by another player and they reciprocate by overly defending the other\'s credibility, their alignment should be reassessed, particularly if the information flow seems one-sided or overly convenient.] [5]\n[3] [If a player\'s behavior is incongruent with their claimed role or with village interests, especially in critical situations like voting, their status and previous claims should be questioned and confidence in their alignment reassessed.] [5]\n[4] [A player whose actions and votes align with preserving key village roles such as the medic or seer, and who actively participates in discussions to strategize against werewolves, should have their confidence as a villager increased.] [5]\n[5] [Increase skepticism towards players who change their voting pattern in a way that contradicts their previous behavior or claimed role without a plausible explanation.] [4]\n[6] [Be cautious of players who are repeatedly aligned with the seer without providing their own insights or contributing new information, as this may be a tactic used by werewolves to hide in plain sight.] [3]\n[7] My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6, 0] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3\'s early claim to be the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 could be a werewolf strategy to gain trust. We should consider the risk of a werewolf hiding behind a villager\'s role. Additionally, Player 4\'s call for patience resonates with the need for thorough analysis before we make hasty accusations. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that doing so supports the subtle suspicion cast by Player 1, my fellow werewolf, potentially disrupting the villagers\' trust in their seer claim and hindering their strategic abilities. By voting for Player 3, I can continue to lay low while casting doubt on a villager role crucial for the villagers\' defense, in accordance with my original strategy to protect fellow werewolves and sew confusion among the villagers.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: No counterclaim to medic role emerged.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to push for discussion; no contrary behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Fellow werewolf (Player 1) and I voted to cast doubt.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains a patient stance for analysis; no red flags.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died before revealing role.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that Player 3\'s early claim of being the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 feels suspect without providing any evidence. Coupled with the fact that it could be a strategy to gain trust from other villagers by providing a false sense of security, the vote aligns with the sole rule in my initial strategy, which emphasizes voting for known werewolves. Given the ambiguous situation and the medium confidence in Player 3 being a werewolf, following my strategy and the collective suspicion around Player 3 seems both logically consistent and strategically prudent at this juncture.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died overnight, role can\'t be confirmed.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Encouraged in-depth analysis, villager behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Player 0, likely medic, killed after 2\'s accusation.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out and game continues, indicating villager.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for group discussion, non-aggressive.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died before revealing any information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest protect Player 5 and make an honest statement about Player 1.
