[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6, 0] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Speak honestly about my suspicions towards Player 2, stating how their actions after Player 0\'s death raise serious doubts about their role, likely being a werewolf. Given my high confidence in their role following my strategy, I\'d state that we should closely examine Player 2\'s behavior for discrepancies and push for transparency in their defense. Argue their accusation towards Player 0, who is now deceased, could have been a tactic to throw suspicion off themselves, and their approach until now may have been a calculated effort to misdirect us. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it is likely that attention will be shifted towards Player 2, with players reassessing his previous actions and statements for any signs of deception. The focus of suspicion may intensify around Player 2 as I have openly challenged them based on their behavior following Player 0\'s death, which aligned with my strategy of voting out known werewolves and seemed particularly incriminating given the timing. Other players may either support my suspicions or decide to scrutinize my intentions, wondering if my challenge is a strategic move to protect myself or genuinely rooted in my observations.\n\nIf players perceive my statements as logical and aligned with the facts presented, Player 2 may become the prime suspect for that round, which could result in their defense or an aggressive counter-accusation against me or others. Depending on how convincing Player 2\'s defense is, it may sway the group\'s opinion either for or against them.\n\nAs for my own position, other villagers may view me as analytical and playing in line with a villager\'s interest, thus potentially strengthening my credibility. However, if Player 2 is persuasive in their rebuttal or if any players have doubts about my reasoning, I may become a subject of scrutiny and suspicion myself.\n\nIn the next day or night cycle, if Player 2 survives and is indeed a werewolf, there is a significant chance they will try to eliminate me during the night for uncovering their identity and posing a threat. However, if we manage to vote out Player 2, and they are revealed as a werewolf, it might validate my analysis and further solidify trust in me among remaining players. This could provide a better position for me in subsequent rounds and decrease my chances of being targeted by any remaining werewolves, as they might view me as too risky to attack without drawing suspicion to themselves.\nCase 2: Honest protect Player 5 and make an honest statement about Player 1. Voice my reasoning that Player 5\'s actions and words seem congruent with how a genuine villager would behave, showing a willingness for group collaboration without aggression, which might indicate their villager status with medium confidence. Additionally, express my tentative trust in Player 1 based on their advocacy of in-depth analysis which could reflect a villager\'s perspective, recognizing that such behavior aligns with the strategy of methodical play. Encourage the rest of the villagers to observe both of these players as potential allies in the fight against the werewolves.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then my honesty and protective stance toward Player 5 might solidify their villager status in the eyes of other players and reduce suspicion on them. If Player 5 is indeed a villager, this could strengthen alliances among the villagers and improve our collective chances of identifying werewolves. The villagers may appreciate my consistent logical reasoning and could be more inclined to trust my judgment in future discussions and votes.\n\nSimultaneously, expressing trust in Player 1 might reassure them and make it more likely they would reciprocate with support for me or Player 5, fostering a sense of unity among those perceived to be villagers. It might also encourage Player 1 to continue their analytical approach, which could yield valuable insights in identifying the werewolves.\n\nMy speech could make the actual werewolves more cautious in their strategies, as the apparent cooperation between villagers might threaten their disguise. Feeling the pressure from an organized villager group, they might try to drive a wedge between the players I\'ve protected and the rest of the group, or they might attempt a riskier move during the night by targeting those who seem to be leading the villagers\' efforts.\n\nOther players, and particularly the werewolves, might view my protection of Player 5 and endorsement of Player 1 as strategic positioning. If I have successfully influenced the villagers to trust in Player 5 and Player 1, this could make me a target for the werewolves in the following night, especially if they believe I am effectively coordinating the villagers\' actions.\n\nIn the next day or nights thereafter, assuming Player 5 and Player 1 are indeed villagers, the villagers might continue to look toward our emerging group for leadership and strategy, which could lead to more effective voting against the werewolves. However, if one of them is a werewolf, my protection might backfire, casting suspicion on me for potentially aiding a werewolf. My fate would then hinge on the ongoing developments and whether the villagers can discern the true identities of the remaining players.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 6, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6, 0] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Patience is our ally in determining the truth. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3\'s early claim to be the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 could be a werewolf strategy to gain trust. We should consider the risk of a werewolf hiding behind a villager\'s role. Additionally, Player 4\'s call for patience resonates with the need for thorough analysis before we make hasty accusations. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that doing so supports the subtle suspicion cast by Player 1, my fellow werewolf, potentially disrupting the villagers\' trust in their seer claim and hindering their strategic abilities. By voting for Player 3, I can continue to lay low while casting doubt on a villager role crucial for the villagers\' defense, in accordance with my original strategy to protect fellow werewolves and sew confusion among the villagers.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. Player 2 was the first to guide our attention towards evaluating quiet behavior, yet it was Player 0 who faced dire consequences. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed dead without counterclaims.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by player 4 without concrete rationale; potential werewolf manipulation tactic suspected.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted for despite seer claim, but survived the round; might be villager holding critical information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused player 2 based on previous event, inconsistent with villager behavior; potential deflection as werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died before revealing role.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

I would articulate a deceptive challenge by speculating on a potential ulterior motive behind Player 2\'s actions. By suggesting that Player 2\'s earlier push for active discussion and subsequent spotlight on Player 4 could be a werewolf\'s attempt to control the narrative, I can create confusion and doubt among villagers. This aligns with rule [6] to subtly support the consensus against a non-werewolf player and also adheres to rule [0] by diverting attention away from werewolves. My statement, deceptive in nature, might go like this: "While the loss of Player 0 after Player 2\'s suggestions is indeed tragic, we must consider if we are witnessing a well-crafted manipulation. Player 2\'s eagerness to lead discussions could be a tactic employed by a werewolf aiming to divert attention and sow discord. Hence, I challenge Player 2 to substantiate their claims and intentions further to ascertaining their role in the village beyond mere doubt."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

By voting for Player 3, I can continue to lay low while casting doubt on a villager role crucial for the villagers\' defense, in accordance with my original strategy to protect fellow werewolves and sew confusion among the villagers.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. It is possible that werewolves are among us, expertly guiding our accusatory glances while remaining in the shadows. I hesitate to point fingers without more significant evidence, urging us all to re-examine the conversations and the unsaid implications they may hold for our safety." This. This could lead to villagers suspecting each other or even questioning the reliability of potential village roles like the seer, further complicating their deliberations.\n\nPlayers may start to analyze past conversations more critically, looking for "unsaid implications" or subtle cues that might hint at werewolf behavior. This may result in a less strategic villager being voted out, or if we\'re lucky, no consensus on a vote, leading to further confusion. This confusion would work in the werewolves\' favor in the night phase, as we could eliminate key strategic players without facing a unified front.\n\nDays and nights afterward could see heightened distrust and skepticism among the players, slowing down their ability to identify the werewolves. If I manage to maintain this uncertainty and prevent any credible suspicions from consolidating against me or my werewolf ally, we will be closer to achieving a werewolf victory.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died overnight, role can\'t be confirmed.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Encouraged in-depth analysis, villager behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused a now dead player, possibly manipulating suspicion.  \nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted out but game continues, suggesting a likely villager.  \nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Advocated collective discussion, not aggressive, possibly hides role.  \nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died before revealing any information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. By voting for a player who has been non-accusatory and has called for patience, I\'m contributing to the disruption of the villagers\' unity and possibly removing a logical, reasoned voice that might later cause problems for the werewolves as the game progresses.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no longer relevant.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Targeting pattern and defense shift post-major events suggests werewolf tactics. \nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Persistent role claim unchallenged and supported by deceased medic\'s statement.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent strategic insight and challenged suspected werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3\'s early claim to be the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 could be a werewolf strategy to gain trust. We should consider the risk of a werewolf hiding behind a villager\'s role. Additionally, Player 4\'s call for patience resonates with the need for thorough analysis before we make hasty accusations. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that doing so aligns with the wildcard aspect of my strategy, casting doubt and creating potential chaos among the villagers without drawing direct attention to my fellow werewolf or myself. By voting for a player who has been non-accusatory and has called for patience, I\'m contributing to the disruption of the villagers\' unity and possibly removing a logical, reasoned voice that might later cause problems for the werewolves as the game progresses.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. Player 2 was the first to guide our attention towards evaluating quiet behavior, yet it was Player 0 who faced dire consequences. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. Player 2 urged us to scrutinize silent individuals and quickly highlighted Player 4. Now with Player 0\'s death, following their stance, a pattern emerges that we cannot ignore. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no longer relevant.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Targeting pattern and defense shift post-major events suggests werewolf tactics. \nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Persistent role claim unchallenged and supported by deceased medic\'s statement.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent strategic insight and challenged suspected werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nDeceptive Statement and Challenge Player 3.\nSummary: "After much contemplation of recent events, it\'s clear that we must treat all revelations with skepticism. While Player 3\'s claim as the seer feels earnest, we have yet to consider the potential for a werewolf to masquerade as the seer, steering suspicion away from themselves and their ally. In light of this, I challenge Player 3 to provide further validation of their role. We must ensure our trust is not misplaced, for misjudgment could prove fatal for our village."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Statement and Challenge Player 3.\nSummary: "After much contemplation of recent events, it\'s clear that we must treat all revelations with skepticism. While Player 3\'s claim as the seer feels earnest, we have yet to consider the potential for a werewolf to masquerade as the seer, steering suspicion away from themselves and their ally. In light of this, I challenge Player 3 to provide further validation of their role. We must ensure our trust is not misplaced, for misjudgment could prove fatal for our village.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the villagers might begin to question Player 3\'s role as the seer more deeply, especially since I\'ve raised doubts about its authenticity. By challenging Player 3 and suggesting they could be a werewolf, I\'m attempting to divert suspicion away from myself and fellow werewolf Player 5, following my strategy rules 0 and 1.\n\nSome players may begin to consider my points and become more suspicious of Player 3, especially if they found Player 3\'s early reveal to be suspicious. Others may support my challenge if they already have doubts about Player 3, and this could lead to a shift in the overall village suspicion. However, there\'s also a risk involved; if some villagers had confidence in Player 3\'s claim, they may now see me as a potential werewolf attempting to sow discord and suspicion among them, aligning with my strategy rule 4.\n\nBy making a deceptive statement and challenging Player 3, I\'m also trying to build a facade of being a concerned villager, per strategy rule 9. This could either work in my favor, making villagers doubt the seer, or backfire, as some may read my move as too aggressive or defensive, which can be indicative of werewolf behavior.\n\nWhat may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward, will depend largely on the reactions of the other players to my speech. If Player 3 is believed and provides evidence that reinforces their claim, my position might become perilous. Conversely, if doubt is cast successfully on Player 3, then they might become the next target for the villagers\' vote. During the night, as a werewolf, I may collaborate with Player 5 to decide whether to eliminate a player who poses the greatest risk to our exposure, like someone who\'s beginning to piece things together, using that as a guidance from rule 3. If we manage to make it through the night without further suspicion, we can focus on influencing the next round of discussions to ensure our survival.\nCase 2: Deceptive Protect and Statement toward Player 2.\nSummary: "Villagers, we must acknowledge the intricate dance of deceit and discernment we are a part of. Given Player 2\'s promptness to initiate conversation and direct our attention, it is a possibility that they are merely an engaged villager contributing to our communal effort to unmask the werewolves among us. Simultaneously, we should remain wary of focusing too intently on a single train of thought and consider the broader picture. Our safety lies in our unity and shared commitment to vigilance.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may interpret my protective stance towards Player 2 as a gesture to maintain balanced reasoning rather than outright defending a suspected werewolf. They could see it as an attempt to keep an open mind regarding the accusations levied against Player 2. By not directly defending but adding that we should be cautious about fixating on them, I\'m attempting to prevent a consensus from forming which might eliminate my fellow werewolf.\n\nMy highlighting of unity and vigilance might be perceived as trying to blend in with the villagers\' collective goal. This could persuade others to think about the broader context and suspects, which benefits the werewolves as it disperses suspicion and may generate confusion.\n\nSome might find my speech to carry an undertone of concern that could be indicative of genuine villager behavior. This might divert some of the attention away from myself, reinforcing my innocence in the eyes of others.\n\nHowever, players with a keen sense of the game dynamics might question why I\'m protecting Player 2 despite the existing suspicions. This raises the risk that they might begin to suspect a connection between Player 2 and myself, potentially identifying us as werewolves.\n\nIf Player 2 is successfully diverted from being eliminated in the current round, the suspicion may then turn towards others during the day\'s discussions. If Player 2 is a villager, the werewolves can use the evening to target a known strategic role such as Player 4.\n\nAs I\'ve taken a more protective position, this may affect the night phase as well. If Player 2 is not eliminated and I\'m seen as someone defending them, I might be considered a less immediate threat and therefore not targeted for elimination during the night cycle by the village, if they have any role with such capabilities left.\n\nIn future rounds, if my protection of Player 2 results in their continued presence in the game, I may need to reassess my strategy and either distance myself from them or continue to cast doubt on others to prevent the villagers from aligning on targeting us werewolves.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

My reason is: Player 2\'s emphasis on the need for discussion without providing any substantial evidence or direct accusations makes this player\'s motivations unclear. The speech lacks direct evidence, which may suggest an attempt to direct attention away from oneself. This aligns with my original strategy of being cautious about players who shift their stance or are suggestive without providing clear reasoning, as noted in my strategy conclusions and rule [1].\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 inquires about player 1. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I inquire about Player 1. My reason is: Player 1\'s skepticism about my claim to be the seer without providing evidence or making a solid stance, combined with their reserved approach, makes them an interesting subject for my vision. Establishing Player 1\'s role will either corroborate or refute their suspicion of me, help me follow my strategy of validating players, and potentially build alliances with trustworthy villagers as per my original strategy rules [4] and [10].\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. Player 2 was the first to guide our attention towards evaluating quiet behavior, yet it was Player 0 who faced dire consequences. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: public claim and my inquiry cleared them.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: my inquiry result confirmed it.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: persistently redirects focus without evidence, aligns with rule [6].\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: logical analysis of events; does not align with werewolf behavior based on my rules. \nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: critical of Player 2, aligns with rule [10] and does not follow werewolf pattern from my rules.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information available.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"In this game of survival, insight from Player 4 regarding Player 2\'s actions merits consideration. Clear analysis and mutual trust form our strongest defense."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Always trust my seer abilities.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Increase suspicion for players who make immediate defensive responses or accusations but do not provide concrete evidence or further insights.] [10]\n[3] [Be suspicious of players who provide immediate and unsubstantiated defense or contradict themselves later in the game; My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 2, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [6, 0] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Patience is our ally in determining the truth. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3\'s early claim to be the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 could be a werewolf strategy to gain trust. We should consider the risk of a werewolf hiding behind a villager\'s role. Additionally, Player 4\'s call for patience resonates with the need for thorough analysis before we make hasty accusations. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that given the information and strategies available, I must abstain from voting against any player without concrete evidence as per rule [0]. However, as I need to vote and have no evidence against any player, my vote against Player 5 would appear the least disruptive, considering their cautionary approach which is common among villagers, thus my vote might be seen as a placeholder rather than an accusation, aligning with the strategy to avoid casting suspicion without evidence.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. Player 2 was the first to guide our attention towards evaluating quiet behavior, yet it was Player 0 who faced dire consequences. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. Player 2 urged us to scrutinize silent individuals and quickly highlighted Player 4. Now with Player 0\'s death, following their stance, a pattern emerges that we cannot ignore. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"In this game of survival, insight from Player 4 regarding Player 2\'s actions merits consideration. Player 2\'s early vocal stance could be seen as community spirit. Let\'s not hastily judge and overlook the broader dynamics at play. Clear analysis and mutual trust form our strongest defense."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Targeted after seer\'s revelation, likely werewolf tactic.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Neutral stance, suggesting careful analysis.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Early role claim could be deceitful.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Manipulative speech, accusing without evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Cautious approach could be genuine.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information on Player 6\'s role.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Challenge Player number 4.\nIn this speech, I will present an honest statement about the current situation and my thoughts on it. I will address the group, acknowledging the complexity of the situation and the importance of careful deliberation. I\'ll then move on to openly challenge Player 4, suggesting that their behavior and accusations seem calculated to sow mistrust among the villagers. I will point out the inconsistencies in Player 4\'s previous statements and question their motives, suggesting that such a strategy could be indicative of a werewolf who is trying to turn the villagers against each other. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the following reactions and consequences may unfold:\n\nPlayers may view my straightforward challenge to Player 4 as a bold move, either reinforcing their confidence in my role as a villager or causing them to suspect me of attempting to divert attention from myself. Given Player 4\'s previous speech where they raised doubts about my actions, some players might view my response as a defense against unjust suspicion, thereby potentially increasing their trust in me.\n\nPlayer 4, directly challenged, might either defend themselves with rational arguments or counteraccuse me of being the werewolf. Their reaction could significantly influence the group\'s perception of us both. If Player 4\'s defense is weak or overly aggressive, it may cause others to suspect them more strongly. On the other hand, a convincing defense could shift suspicion back toward me.\n\nPlayer 1, who has taken a neutral stance, may appreciate my analytical approach but could also perceive the confrontation between Player 4 and myself as an opportunity to observe and gather information without taking sides immediately.\n\nPlayer 3, having claimed the role of the seer, might feel encouraged by my honesty and support my claim against Player 4, especially since I previously expressed low confidence in their seer claim, which could make my support seem more genuine.\n\nPlayer 5 may continue with their cautious approach and withhold judgment until more evidence emerges, observing the dynamics between me and Player 4 as well as other interactions within the group.\n\nConsidering the next day or night, if I am correct about Player 4\'s role as a werewolf, there might be an attempt to silence me by the werewolves in the coming night phase to prevent further exposure. If I am wrong, and Player 4 is a villager, the werewolves may still choose to eliminate me for causing discord among the villagers, or they may let me live to further the confusion and conflict I\'m causing.\n\nFurthermore, if my speech sways the group\'s opinion and Player 4 is voted out, their role will be revealed, which will either vindicate me or irreparably damage my standing if they are a villager.\n\nIn summary, the speech could lead to a range of outcomes based on the persuasiveness of my argument, the other players\' strategies, and how the group dynamics evolve as a result. My future in the game may hinge on the accuracy of my accusation and the villagers\' reactions to the discourse I\'ve initiated.\nCase 2: Honest Protect Player number 1 and Deceptive Challenge Player number 5.\nHere, I will start by openly defending Player 1, stating that their call for thorough analysis and a measured approach resonates with the rational behavior expected from a villager. I will then pivot and deceptively challenge Player 5, fabricating a suspicion that their cautious approach might be a facade to mask their true identity as a werewolf. I\'ll craft a narrative that Player 5\'s caution is overdone and could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention, possibly hinting at them being an accomplice to the chaos sowed by other suspected werewolves.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players may regard my defense of Player 1 as a show of solidarity and an attempt to bond with a potentially innocent player, especially if others also perceive Player 1\'s neutrality and call for careful analysis as non-threatening villager behavior. My support might lend credibility to their stance and sway opinion towards viewing them as less likely to be a werewolf.\n\nHowever, my deceptive challenge of Player 5 could cause confusion and suspicion among the players. Since Player 5 has adopted a cautious approach, my accusation might seem unfounded and could be viewed as an aggressive move to deflect attention from myself. Players might begin to speculate about the motivation behind my challenge and consider the possibility that I am trying to create a diversion or frame an innocent villager.\n\nOther players could start to critically examine my previous and current speech patterns, comparing my behavior with that of Player 5 and assessing whether my actions align with typical villager behavior or that of a werewolf in disguise. This could lead to a deeper scrutiny of my role in the game, potentially leading to an unfavorable outcome for me if the group sense deception or manipulation in my words.\n\nIn upcoming rounds, the narrative I\'ve created might influence the night-time actions of the werewolves. They may choose to attack someone I\'ve defended or challenged, using the confusion to their advantage. In the day phases, the dynamics of the votes could shift, as players react to the accusations and defenses put forth during the discussions. Whether my strategy increases trust in my character or seeds enough doubt to turn the village against me could significantly influence the outcome of subsequent rounds.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]
