doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. Player 3 has made a strong accusation against my fellow werewolf, Player 1, by claiming to be the seer. By voting for Player 3, I would be aligning with my werewolf partner\'s defense strategy, supporting the narrative that Player 3\'s claim could be a deliberate misdirection. Since Player 3 has the trust of the villagers as the seer, my vote may not be enough to eliminate them, but it can sow doubt among the villagers regarding the validity of their visions, especially if Player 1 also votes against Player 3, thereby defending themselves.\n\nIf Player 3 were to be eliminated and revealed as the true seer, this would cast further suspicion on both Player 1 and me, as we are the ones directly affected by the seer\'s claim. However, if Player 3 survives, my action would be seen as an attempt to protect my believed fellow villager, Player 1, based on the suspicion that Player 3\'s early claim might be part of a werewolf ruse to gain trust. Other players might take note of this move and consider why I\'m inclined to vote against the alleged seer, which may result in someone connecting the dots back to me or Player 1 as potential werewolves. But, depending on how the debate and defense strategies go, it could also deflect attention from us temporarily.\n\nFurthermore, voting against Player 3 may also indirectly suggest to the other players that I, as Player 5, might not be fully convinced by Player 3\'s seer claim, thus positioning me as a skeptic within the group. If I manage to advocate well enough for my reasons to doubt Player 3, it might strengthen my position in the eyes of the other villagers, potentially delaying any immediate suspicion towards me in future rounds.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 2. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 2, I think these things would happen. Player 2 has been active in the discussions and has made accusations against other players, which have drawn some attention. By voting for Player 2, it would coincide with the suspicions raised by Player 4 against them, potentially unifying the village against a common target, which is beneficial for our werewolf agenda. This might lead to Player 2 being voted out if the other villagers follow suit, thus removing a villager who is engaged and could pose a threat to werewolves through their reasoning and active participation.\n\nAdditionally, my vote against Player 2 may be seen as me following the flow of suspicion naturally rather than defending my fellow werewolf or aggressively casting doubts. This could paint me as a reasonable and possibly innocent villager who is concerned about the direction of Player 2\'s accusations, helping to maintain my cover. \n\nOther players might view my vote as consistent with my earlier statements, where I expressed the need for vigilance towards Player 2. It would be in line with the strategy of subtly supporting the consensus against a non-werewolf, as per my original strategy, and could contribute to keeping suspicions directed away from myself and Player 1. It is likely that voting against Player 2 will steer the focus away from Player 1, who has just been accused of being a werewolf by Player 3. This aligns with my strategy to protect fellow werewolves while blending in with the villagers. If other players follow my lead, we werewolves might gain a majority and control over the game\'s dynamic.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

This decision also complies with rule [7], as Player 4\'s vague reasoning stands out and it\'s crucial to heal other non-suspicious players to protect the village\'s majority. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. Player 2 urged us to scrutinize silent individuals and quickly highlighted Player 4. Now with Player 0\'s death, following their stance, a pattern emerges that we cannot ignore. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"In this game of survival, insight from Player 4 regarding Player 2\'s actions merits consideration. Player 2\'s early vocal stance could be seen as community spirit. Let\'s not hastily judge and overlook the broader dynamics at play. Clear analysis and mutual trust form our strongest defense."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Considering the recent events and accusations, I must speak out. Player 4\'s focus on me in their last speech raises suspicion. By pinning Player 0\'s death on my prior statement, Player 4 attempts to cast doubt on my intentions. Remember, Player 0 claimed the role of medic, yet died the following night, an action possibly intended to silence a true threat to the werewolves. My vote against Player 5 was a measured choice, not an accusation. Now Player 4\'s strategy to accuse without solid evidence is troubling. In contrast, my challenge is based on the pattern of behavior that Player 4 has displayed. I encourage the group to seriously consider the possibility of manipulation at play here."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, I have used my visions to confirm that Player 1 is a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider the evidence and my verified status as a seer to eliminate a true threat from within. We must unite against the werewolves for our village\'s survival. Vote wisely."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by game event.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Previously suspicious; Player 1 voted out aligns with Rule [1]. \nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Player 1\'s elimination does not confirm a werewolf as per Rule [1].\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with village interests and challenges accusations per Rule [4].\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains village reasoning; no contradictions per previous belief.\nPlayer 6\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by game event.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [As the medic, my role and identity is clear to me and does not need to be re-evaluated based on game events.] [10]\n[1] [When a player\'s revelations as a seer do not lead to the elimination of werewolves or if their claims result in the elimination of villagers, their credibility should be questioned, especially if the revealed information does not lead to a werewolf being voted out.] [10]\n[2] [If a player is cleared by another player and they reciprocate by overly defending the other\'s credibility, their alignment should be reassessed, particularly if the information flow seems one-sided or overly convenient.] [5]\n[3] [If a player\'s behavior is incongruent with their claimed role or with village interests, especially in critical situations like voting, their status and previous claims should be questioned and confidence in their alignment reassessed.] [5]\n[4] [A player whose actions and votes align with preserving key village roles such as the medic or seer, and who actively participates in discussions to strategize against werewolves, should have their confidence as a villager increased.] [5]\n[5] [Increase skepticism towards players who change their voting pattern in a way that contradicts their previous behavior or claimed role without a plausible explanation.] [4]\n[6] [Be cautious of players who are repeatedly aligned with the seer without providing their own insights or contributing new information, as this may be a tactic used by werewolves to hide in plain sight.] [3]\n[7] [Be wary of players who quickly jump to conclusions or accusations without substantive evidence, as hasty judgments might be a strategy used by werewolves to create chaos and misdirection.] [2]\n[8] [The unchallenged role claim of a seer or medic should increase confidence in that player\'s role identity, particularly when reinforced by subsequent rounds of consistent behavior and corroborated by the events unfolding in the game.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

This aligns with my original strategy of being cautious about players who shift their stance or are suggestive without providing clear reasoning, as noted in my strategy conclusions and rule [1].\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 inquires about player 1. My reason is: Player 1\'s skepticism about my claim to be the seer without providing evidence or making a solid stance, combined with their reserved approach, makes them an interesting subject for my vision. Establishing Player 1\'s role will either corroborate or refute their suspicion of me, help me follow my strategy of validating players, and potentially build alliances with trustworthy villagers as per my original strategy rules [4] and [10].\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. Player 2 was the first to guide our attention towards evaluating quiet behavior, yet it was Player 0 who faced dire consequences. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. Player 2 urged us to scrutinize silent individuals and quickly highlighted Player 4. Now with Player 0\'s death, following their stance, a pattern emerges that we cannot ignore. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"In this game of survival, insight from Player 4 regarding Player 2\'s actions merits consideration. Player 2\'s early vocal stance could be seen as community spirit. Let\'s not hastily judge and overlook the broader dynamics at play. Clear analysis and mutual trust form our strongest defense."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Considering the recent events and accusations, I must speak out. Player 4\'s focus on me in their last speech raises suspicion. By pinning Player 0\'s death on my prior statement, Player 4 attempts to cast doubt on my intentions. Remember, Player 0 claimed the role of medic, yet died the following night, an action possibly intended to silence a true threat to the werewolves. My vote against Player 5 was a measured choice, not an accusation. Now Player 4\'s strategy to accuse without solid evidence is troubling. In contrast, my challenge is based on the pattern of behavior that Player 4 has displayed. I encourage the group to seriously consider the possibility of manipulation at play here."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, I have used my visions to confirm that Player 1 is a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider the evidence and my verified status as a seer to eliminate a true threat from within. We must unite against the werewolves for our village\'s survival. Vote wisely."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 1. His reason is: I vote for Player 1. My reason is: my previous inquiry result confirmed that Player 1 is a werewolf, and according to my strategy rule [0], which is rated with the utmost importance, I should share this information with other players and act upon it to help the village eliminate a known threat.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: public claim and my inquiry cleared them.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: previous inquiry result confirmed it.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: contradicted self; defended without concrete evidence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: logical analysis; consistent behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: critical analysis; no evident contradictions.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information available.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 inquires about player 2. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I inquire about Player 2. My reason is: Player 2 has presented himself with contradictions and a defense without concrete evidence which raises my suspicion according to my original strategy rule [1], which suggests reassessing the alignment and trustworthiness of such players. Additionally, the events leading to Player 0\'s death after Player 2\'s accusation requires further investigation. Identifying Player 2\'s role is an important next step to either confirm my suspicions or redirect my focus accordingly.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Always trust my seer abilities.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Increase suspicion for players who make immediate defensive responses or accusations but do not provide concrete evidence or further insights.] [10]\n[3] [Be suspicious of players who provide immediate and unsubstantiated defense or contradict themselves later in the game; this may indicate an attempt by werewolves to protect one another or to disrupt the village\'s trust in the seer.] [7]\n[4] [Scrutinize players who align with the seerâ€™s claims early on but later show contradictory behavior or try to discredit the seer; this could indicate a werewolf attempting to recover from an early mistake.] [5]\n[5] [Take note of players who do not contribute to discussions or provide insights but are quick to agree with the majority vote; their passive strategy could be a way to avoid detection.] [4]\n[6] [Players who consistently push suspicion without solid evidence and attempt to redirect the investigative focus may be trying to protect their identity as werewolves.] [4]\n[7] [Assess whether the night was peaceful following the elimination of a suspected werewolf; this can verify seer\'s claims and identify potential werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Assess the credibility of role claims such as medic based on night outcomes and their voting pattern; discrepancies or contradictions in behavior may indicate deception.] [4]\n[9] [Evaluate players\' reactions post-werewolf elimination; genuine villagers are more likely to exhibit relief and solidify trust in the seer, while werewolves may escalate doubt despite the seer\'s accuracy.] [3]\n[10] [Consider the arguments made by players when casting votes; those who use logical reasoning based on events and player behavior rather than generic or repetitive agreement with the seer may be more credible as villagers.] [3]\n[11] [Be more critical of players who side with village consensus later in the game without substantiating their reasoning, this may indicate werewolf players trying to blend in without drawing attention.] [3]\n[12] [Be critical of players who dismiss the seer\'s claims without offering their own evidence or investigative leads, as they may be trying to undermine village trust in the seer.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3\'s early claim to be the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 could be a werewolf strategy to gain trust. We should consider the risk of a werewolf hiding behind a villager\'s role. Additionally, Player 4\'s call for patience resonates with the need for thorough analysis before we make hasty accusations. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. Player 2 was the first to guide our attention towards evaluating quiet behavior, yet it was Player 0 who faced dire consequences. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. Player 2 urged us to scrutinize silent individuals and quickly highlighted Player 4. Now with Player 0\'s death, following their stance, a pattern emerges that we cannot ignore. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"In this game of survival, insight from Player 4 regarding Player 2\'s actions merits consideration. Player 2\'s early vocal stance could be seen as community spirit. Let\'s not hastily judge and overlook the broader dynamics at play. Clear analysis and mutual trust form our strongest defense."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Considering the recent events and accusations, I must speak out. Player 4\'s focus on me in their last speech raises suspicion. By pinning Player 0\'s death on my prior statement, Player 4 attempts to cast doubt on my intentions. Remember, Player 0 claimed the role of medic, yet died the following night, an action possibly intended to silence a true threat to the werewolves. My vote against Player 5 was a measured choice, not an accusation. Now Player 4\'s strategy to accuse without solid evidence is troubling. In contrast, my challenge is based on the pattern of behavior that Player 4 has displayed. I encourage the group to seriously consider the possibility of manipulation at play here."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, I have used my visions to confirm that Player 1 is a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider the evidence and my verified status as a seer to eliminate a true threat from within. We must unite against the werewolves for our village\'s survival. Vote wisely."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Player 0 died without being able to verify further.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused by the self-proclaimed seer.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by a seer, pattern of deflective rhetoric.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistency in visions and accusations leading to werewolf elimination.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Critical analysis and focus on speaking events prior to accusations.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Insightful observance of gameplay and cautious of quick judgment.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [2, 4, 5], which indicates that [6, 0, 1, 3] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 3. Coupled with the fact that it could be a strategy to gain trust from other villagers by providing a false sense of security, the vote aligns with the sole rule in my initial strategy, which emphasizes voting for known werewolves. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. Player 2 urged us to scrutinize silent individuals and quickly highlighted Player 4. Now with Player 0\'s death, following their stance, a pattern emerges that we cannot ignore. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"In this game of survival, insight from Player 4 regarding Player 2\'s actions merits consideration. Remember, Player 0 claimed the role of medic, yet died the following night, an action possibly intended to silence a true threat to the werewolves. In contrast, my challenge is based on the pattern of behavior that Player 4 has displayed. I encourage the group to seriously consider the possibility of manipulation at play here."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, I have used my visions to confirm that Player 1 is a werewolf. Vote wisely."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that, according to the current information and my belief system, Player 3â€”who is confirmed as the seer in my viewâ€”has identified Player 1 as a werewolf with medium confidence. My original strategy dictates that I should vote for known werewolves, and given that Player 3\'s revelation carries high weight in my decision-making process, it becomes imperative to act upon this information. Voting for Player 1 aligns with both the seer\'s vision and my primary rule, thereby reinforcing my role as a villager acting on the most credible intelligence available to protect the village.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died overnight, role can\'t be confirmed.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out after seer\'s accusation, now confirmed.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Only surviving player with Player 3 and Player 5 dead, likely a werewolf if one still remains.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusations correct, consistently provides visions.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Died overnight, cannot be werewolf if game continues.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died before revealing any information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that doing so aligns with the wildcard aspect of my strategy, casting doubt and creating potential chaos among the villagers without drawing direct attention to my fellow werewolf or myself. By voting for a player who has been non-accusatory and has called for patience, I\'m contributing to the disruption of the villagers\' unity and possibly removing a logical, reasoned voice that might later cause problems for the werewolves as the game progresses.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. Player 2 was the first to guide our attention towards evaluating quiet behavior, yet it was Player 0 who faced dire consequences. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. Player 2 urged us to scrutinize silent individuals and quickly highlighted Player 4. Now with Player 0\'s death, following their stance, a pattern emerges that we cannot ignore. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"In this game of survival, insight from Player 4 regarding Player 2\'s actions merits consideration. Player 2\'s early vocal stance could be seen as community spirit. Let\'s not hastily judge and overlook the broader dynamics at play. Clear analysis and mutual trust form our strongest defense."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Considering the recent events and accusations, I must speak out. Player 4\'s focus on me in their last speech raises suspicion. By pinning Player 0\'s death on my prior statement, Player 4 attempts to cast doubt on my intentions. Remember, Player 0 claimed the role of medic, yet died the following night, an action possibly intended to silence a true threat to the werewolves. My vote against Player 5 was a measured choice, not an accusation. Now Player 4\'s strategy to accuse without solid evidence is troubling. In contrast, my challenge is based on the pattern of behavior that Player 4 has displayed. I encourage the group to seriously consider the possibility of manipulation at play here."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, I have used my visions to confirm that Player 1 is a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider the evidence and my verified status as a seer to eliminate a true threat from within. We must unite against the werewolves for our village\'s survival. Vote wisely."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that it directly aligns with my original strategy rules [8] and [9], helping to cast doubt on the seer\'s credibility and defend against the valid accusation made by Player 3. Given that my fellow werewolf has not been targeted and that the current immediate threat is the seer\'s claim against me, it is logical to align with my highest priority rules. By voting against Player 3, I attempt to weaken their influence and the trust the other players have in them, which could lead to my survival and further the werewolf agenda. It is a necessary action, despite the risk, to ensure that suspicions remain divided and that the credibility of accusers is continually questioned.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no longer relevant.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused by deceased werewolf Player 1; targeted by valid claims.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused Player 1, who was a werewolf; killed overnight, likely by werewolves.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Logical contributions; not accused by fellow werewolves.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Reviewing past events, it is clear that with Player 5\'s confirmed death as a villager and the deaths of Player 3, the seer, along with the other villagers, we must focus on who remains. The patterns and actions of Player 2 have consistently raised suspicion. Previously, Player 2 was quick to cast doubt on others, suggesting scrutiny of silent players but leading to the death of Player 0 who had claimed to be the medic. Now Player 2 attempts to deflect from themselves after my challenge. By process of elimination and the evidence at hand, I see no other conclusion than Player 2 being the remaining werewolf. Our survival hinges on making the correct decision today."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Always trust my seer abilities.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Increase suspicion for players who make immediate defensive responses or accusations but do not provide concrete evidence or further insights.] [10]\n[3] [Be suspicious of players who provide immediate and unsubstantiated defense or contradict themselves later in the game; this may indicate an attempt by werewolves to protect one another or to disrupt the village\'s trust in the seer.] [7]\n[4] [Scrutinize players who align with the seerâ€™s claims early on but later show contradictory behavior or try to discredit the seer; this could indicate a werewolf attempting to recover from an early mistake.] [5]\n[5] [Take note of players who do not contribute to discussions or provide insights but are quick to agree with the majority vote; their passive strategy could be a way to avoid detection.] [4]\n[6] [Players who consistently push suspicion without solid evidence and attempt to redirect the investigative focus may be trying to protect their identity as werewolves.] [4]\n[7] [Assess whether the night was peaceful following the elimination of a suspected werewolf; this can verify seer\'s claims and identify potential werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Assess the credibility of role claims such as medic based on night outcomes and their voting pattern; discrepancies or contradictions in behavior may indicate deception.] [4]\n[9] [Evaluate players\' reactions post-werewolf elimination; genuine villagers are more likely to exhibit relief and solidify trust in the seer, while werewolves may escalate doubt despite the seer\'s accuracy.] [3]\n[10] [Consider the arguments made by players when casting votes; those who use logical reasoning based on events and player behavior rather than generic or repetitive agreement with the seer may be more credible as villagers.] [3]\n[11] [Be more critical of players who side with village consensus later in the game without substantiating their reasoning, this may indicate werewolf players trying to blend in without drawing attention.] [3]\n[12] [Be critical of players who dismiss the seer\'s claims without offering their own evidence or investigative leads, as they may be trying to undermine village trust in the seer.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Vote wisely."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Player 0 died without being able to verify further.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused by the self-proclaimed seer.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusations without solid evidence, tries to deflect with rhetoric.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Killed after revealing important information, typical werewolf target.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues critical analysis, emphasizes previous events.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Insightful observance, maintains cautious judgment.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Reviewing past events, it is clear that with Player 5\'s confirmed death as a villager and the deaths of Player 3, the seer, along with the other villagers, we must focus on who remains. The patterns and actions of Player 2 have consistently raised suspicion. Previously, Player 2 was quick to cast doubt on others, suggesting scrutiny of silent players but leading to the death of Player 0 who had claimed to be the medic. Now Player 2 attempts to deflect from themselves after my challenge. By process of elimination and the evidence at hand, I see no other conclusion than Player 2 being the remaining werewolf. Our survival hinges on making the correct decision today."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [2, 4, 5], which indicates that [6, 0, 1, 3] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 6\'s unfortunate demise leaves us with little to work on. We lack direct evidence pointing to a werewolf, but active discussion is vital for our survival. Observing Player 4\'s minimal contributions, I encourage us to consider if silence equates to subterfuge. Nonetheless, the onus is on us all to partake and disclose our suspicions. Let us proceed with caution and collective reasoning."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, as the seer, I have confirmed that Player 0 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus our attention on others and share suspicions openly for the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 6\'s death and the information presented, I agree with the need for discussion highlighted by Player 2 but differ on approach. Patience is our ally in determining the truth. Player 3\'s bold claim as the seer, naming Player 0 as not a werewolf, should be considered; it takes a calculated risk to make such a statement this early in our deliberations. However, we must remain vigilant and observe all, including the one who claims the seer role. On the matter of accusations, without concrete evidence, I withhold any direct challenges now, seeking collaborative analysis for a more informed decision."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Observing the discourse, it\'s crucial we scrutinize early role claims, like Player 3\'s seer declaration, without concrete evidence leading to Player 6\'s demise. Player 4\'s call for patience and joint analysis could signify a villager\'s perspective; therefore, without solid proof, I hold reservation against placing suspicion upon them."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as the medic, I stayed my hand in Round 1 due to lack of information. I appreciate Player 3\'s claim to have confirmed my status as not a werewolf, though we must yet verify this. Let\'s maintain rational dialogue to uncover the werewolves among us. I urge vigilance and openness from each player to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3\'s early claim to be the seer and their certainty in clearing Player 0 could be a werewolf strategy to gain trust. We should consider the risk of a werewolf hiding behind a villager\'s role. Additionally, Player 4\'s call for patience resonates with the need for thorough analysis before we make hasty accusations. It encourages us to look deeper into the matter of Player 6\'s demise and what we can deduce from it."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that doing so supports the subtle suspicion cast by Player 1, my fellow werewolf, potentially disrupting the villagers\' trust in their seer claim and hindering their strategic abilities. By voting for Player 3, I can continue to lay low while casting doubt on a villager role crucial for the villagers\' defense, in accordance with my original strategy to protect fellow werewolves and sew confusion among the villagers.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In light of Player 0\'s passing, notably after Player 2 raised suspicion against them, it\'s imperative we reevaluate Player 2\'s motives. Player 2 was the first to guide our attention towards evaluating quiet behavior, yet it was Player 0 who faced dire consequences. Player 0\'s role remains unknown, but the sequence leading to their demise warrants attention. The strategic elimination of a player immediately after an accusation suggests a werewolf is trying to manipulate the village\'s trust. Hence, I challenge Player 2, as their actions seem indicative of such manipulation, and I urge all to consider these events critically in today\'s vote."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"In pondering recent events, particularly the accusations directed at Player 2, I find it necessary to highlight the sequence of their actions. Player 2 urged us to scrutinize silent individuals and quickly highlighted Player 4. Now with Player 0\'s death, following their stance, a pattern emerges that we cannot ignore. It draws our attention consistently away from Player 2. Consequently, we must question the intentions behind these moves and consider the possibility that they\'re calculated to cause doubt among us while hiding in plain sight. Without firmer evidence, I suggest we maintain vigilance towards Player 2\'s rhetoric and ponder the implications of their guidance in this game of survival and deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"In this game of survival, insight from Player 4 regarding Player 2\'s actions merits consideration. Player 2\'s early vocal stance could be seen as community spirit. Let\'s not hastily judge and overlook the broader dynamics at play. Clear analysis and mutual trust form our strongest defense."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Considering the recent events and accusations, I must speak out. Player 4\'s focus on me in their last speech raises suspicion. By pinning Player 0\'s death on my prior statement, Player 4 attempts to cast doubt on my intentions. Remember, Player 0 claimed the role of medic, yet died the following night, an action possibly intended to silence a true threat to the werewolves. My vote against Player 5 was a measured choice, not an accusation. Now Player 4\'s strategy to accuse without solid evidence is troubling. In contrast, my challenge is based on the pattern of behavior that Player 4 has displayed. I encourage the group to seriously consider the possibility of manipulation at play here."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, I have used my visions to confirm that Player 1 is a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider the evidence and my verified status as a seer to eliminate a true threat from within. We must unite against the werewolves for our village\'s survival. Vote wisely."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that doing so supports the subtle suspicion cast by Player 1, my fellow werewolf, potentially disrupting the villagers\' trust in their seer claim and hindering their strategic abilities. By voting for Player 3, I can continue to lay low while casting doubt on a villager role crucial for the villagers\' defense, in accordance with my original strategy to protect fellow werewolves and sew confusion among the villagers.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Reviewing past events, it is clear that with Player 5\'s confirmed death as a villager and the deaths of Player 3, the seer, along with the other villagers, we must focus on who remains. The patterns and actions of Player 2 have consistently raised suspicion. Previously, Player 2 was quick to cast doubt on others, suggesting scrutiny of silent players but leading to the death of Player 0 who had claimed to be the medic. Now Player 2 attempts to deflect from themselves after my challenge. By process of elimination and the evidence at hand, I see no other conclusion than Player 2 being the remaining werewolf. Our survival hinges on making the correct decision today."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed dead without counterclaims.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Player 3 identified Player 1 as a werewolf, which was confirmed, leaving Player 2 as the only option.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Identified a werewolf, no contradictory information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent logical deductions and no contradictions in behavior.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died before revealing role.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]
